Preview and render your blog

To preview the site, use the preview command in the terminal:

File
Description

Directory containing posts

index.qmd: Blog home page
index.qmd will be the landing page for your site.

When creating a new blog, it will default to the listing page for the documents in the posts directory.
If you prefer that the About page is your landing page, you can rename your index.qmd to posts.qmd and about.qmd to index.qmd.

---
title: "my-new-blog"
listing:
  contents: posts
  sort: "date desc"
  type: default
  categories: true
  sort-ui: false
  filter-ui: false
page-layout: full
title-block-banner: true
---
Let‚Äôs go through each line:

title
The title of your listing page.


listing
listings generates the contents of a page (or region of a page) from a set of Quarto documents or other custom data.


contents
contents control what documents are included in the listing by specifying a set of input files.


sort
sort controls the order of the listing.


type
type controls how the listings look.
Three default styles:






Grid





Table





Default





You can write custom listings in Embedded JavaScript templating (EJS).
Tooting my own horn:



Listing made with EJS on ivelasq.rbind.io




categories
categories display the categories for your posts. The categories are read from the YAML of the documents included in the listing.


sort-ui
sort-ui provides a sorting box for readers.


filter-ui
filter-ui provides a filtering box for readers.


page-layout
page-layout controls the layout used.


title-block-banner
title-block-banner positions a formatted title block at the start of the article.






Try it out!



In the index.qmd file of your Quarto blog:

Change the title of your listing page.
Choose another listing type.
Change the sort option to date asc.
What happens when you change filter-ui to true?

image: profile.jpg

_quarto.yml: Quarto project file
The _quarto.yml file is the configuration file for your website.


The Quarto documentation lists the possible top navigation options.
project:
  type: website

website:
  title: "my-new-blog"
  navbar:
    right:
      - about.qmd
      - icon: github
        href: https://github.com/
      - icon: twitter
        href: https://twitter.com
format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
    css: styles.css

editor: visual
Let‚Äôs go through each line:

project
The type of project (vs book, etc.).


title
The title of your blog.


navbar
The navigation bar at the top of your website.


right
The option to specify items for the right side of the navbar.


- about.qmd
The file to be linked. The title will default to the document‚Äôs title.


- icon
The icon to be shown.


href
The link associated with the icon.
There are other options available for the top level navigation. For example, if we want to change the background to an orange, we could add:
  navbar:
    background: "#C45508"






Make sure that you are indenting correctly!



There are also other options for the individual navigation items. For example, if we want to add text to the right side:
  navbar:
    right:
      - text: "my name here"

Quarto top navigation documentation

In the _quarto.yml file of your Quarto blog:

Change the background to a different color.
Add another hyperlink in the navigation bar.
Add your name to the left side of the navigation bar.

title: Migrate from R Markdown
text:
Quarto is designed to be highly compatible with existing R Markdown documents

You should generally be able to use Quarto to render any existing .Rmd document without changes.
Changing a .Rmd file to .qmd forces it into a Quarto document.

If you run into any errors, go into the file to see what occurred.






Try it out!



In the exercise blog:

Render the .Rmd file in the rmarkdown-post folder.

title: Migrate from R Markdown
text:
Code chunk options
One important difference between R Markdown documents and Quarto documents is that in Quarto chunk options are typically included in ‚Äúhashpipes‚Äù at the top of code chunks rather than within the line that begins the chunk:



```{r, echo = FALSE, fig-cap = "Air Quality"}
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(airquality, aes(Temp, Ozone)) + 
        geom_point() + 
        geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE)
```


```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-cap: "Air Quality"

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(airquality, aes(Temp, Ozone)) + 
        geom_point() + 
        geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE)
```



In the newest version of knitr (v1.40), use the function convert_chunk_header() to convert the old in-header chunk options to the new in-body chunk options.
# convert to Quarto doc with in-body chunk options
knitr::convert_chunk_header("to-convert.Rmd", "converted.qmd")
# convert to .Rmd doc with in-body chunk options
knitr::convert_chunk_header("to-convert.Rmd", "converted.Rmd")

title: Publishing your blog
text:
Destination
Description




Quarto Pub
Publishing service for Quarto documents, websites, and books. Use Quarto Pub when you want a free, easy to use service for publicly available content.


GitHub Pages
Publish content based on source code managed within a GitHub repository. Use GitHub Pages when the source code for your document or site is hosted on GitHub.


RStudio Connect
Publishing platform for secure sharing of data products within an organization. Use RStudio Connect when you want to publish content within an organization rather than on the public internet.


Netlify
Professional web publishing platform. Use Netlify when you want support for custom domains, authentication, previewing branches, and other more advanced capabilities.


Other Services
Content rendered with Quarto uses standard formats (HTML, PDFs, MS Word, etc.) that can be published anywhere. Use this if one of the methods above don‚Äôt meet your requirements.




Quarto Pub
Quarto Pub (https://quartopub.com/) is a free publishing service for content created with Quarto. Quarto Pub is ideal for blogs, course or project websites, books, presentations, and personal hobby sites.

Publicly visible
Can be no larger than 100 MB
Have a softlimit of 10 GB of bandwidth per month

title: Literate programming in Quarto
text:
Using R/Python/Julia/Observable
Quarto supports executable code blocks within markdown.

Need to have the appropriate engine installed
Quarto can guess the engine or you can call it explicitly in the YAML


Quarto computations documentation 


Code Blocks
Code blocks that use braces around the language name (e.g.¬†{r}) are executable, and will be run by Quarto during render.

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(airquality, aes(Temp, Ozone)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "loess"
)




Figure¬†2: Temperature and ozone level.






Execution options
You can customize executed code with execution options. They can be specified globally:
---
title: "My Document"
execute:
  echo: false
jupyter: python3
---
Or on a per-chunk basis:
```{python}
#| echo: true

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.plot([1,2,3,4])
plt.show()
```
Note the use of the hashpipe #| at the top of the chunk.
